description: Borrowed from Latin disruptus, from disrumpo, commonly dirumpo (“to break or burst asunder”), from dis-, di- (“apart, asunder”) + rumpo (“to break”).

adjectives.description: disrupt (comparative more disrupt, superlative most disrupt)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Torn off or torn asunder; severed; disrupted.

verbs.description: disrupt (third-person singular simple present disrupts, present participle disrupting, simple past and past participle disrupted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw into confusion or disorder.

examples: Work on the tunnel was disrupted by a strike.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To improve a product or service in ways that displace an established one and surprise the market.
examples: The internet makes it easier for leaner businesses to disrupt the larger and more unwieldy ones.
